hi

i have a question about the concept of chaincode execution. i have compiled a chaincode. as far as i know, the workflow of using a chaincode is as below:
1. write it and compile it into an executable
2. upload it somewhere and run it
3. “deploy” it (and the init function is called at this step)
4. “use” it (i can now call the invoke or query functions)

i have a few questions:
1. as the binary must be put somewhere to run, how is it related to the server running the peer? for ethereum, their smart contract code is really deployed to every blockchain node in the network, because the code are interpreted to some byte code format and uploaded to the blockchain. however, for fabric, the execution is done by the chaincode executable. so it must be put to servers manually. then how can we achieve the redundancy of having multiple peers when running chaincode?
2. what does the “deploy” action actually do? it is specific to the peer i run the “deploy” action against, or it does something to the blockchain network globally? Thanks!
<@U1STYFZK3|thirumanoj> has joined the channel

i have a chaincode deployed on all the nodes as a container. Now that i have updated some logic (another version) of same chaincode.. is there a way i can remove the chaincode deployed in hyperledger and redeploy the new chaincode ??
<@U1GLPP8QN|deeflorian> has joined the channel

Hi!
<@U19PSLZV1>: when you deploy a CC, you connect to a single peer (hence the core peer address parameter) that'll deploy the chaincode. Then that peer will automatically broadcast the CC as a message to the other peers. The deploy messages themselves will eventually end up getting handled in the core/container module, which will in turn launch a docker container that'll host the CC. This is done by every peer when they receive the broadcasted message -- which means there is no need to run the CC manually at all, just make the CC accessible to the first peer, and the deploy action takes care of the rest.

<@U1STYFZK3>: you'll need to remove the docker containers that are created for your previous chaincode (I don't think it's needed, but the peers themselves might have stored some info about them -- I have a script that removes the peers and the CCs too, that'll do the trick if the chaincode removal isn't enough -- also, if your peers aren't running in docker containers, the /var/hyperledger folder's contents should be cleaned).
<@U1GLPP8QN>. Tnx for the response. My four node peers are actual process running on virtual machines.  can you tell me.. what all things needs to be cleaned apart from the docker CC containers.
or can you share your script

<@U1GLPP8QN|deeflorian> uploaded a file: <https://hyperledgerproject.slack.com/files/deeflorian/F1T2TCT1N/-.txt|Untitled> and commented: I use this as a cleaner... The docker parts are actually documented somewhere on the wiki.

file.name: -.txt
file.title: Untitled
file.preview:
docker rm $(docker ps -a -q)
docker rmi $(docker images | grep none | tr -s " " | cut -f 3 -d " ")
docker rmi $(docker images | grep dev | cut -f 1 -d " ")
cd /var/hyperledger
rm -r -f ./*
file.preview_highlight:
docker rm $(docker ps -a -q)
docker rmi $(docker images | grep none | tr -s " " | cut -f 3 -d " ")
docker rmi $(docker images | grep dev | cut -f 1 -d " ")
cd /var/hyperledger
rm -r -f ./*

initial_comment.comment: I use this as a cleaner... The docker parts are actually documented somewhere on the wiki.

How can an "Invoke" completion be detected without having to poll the chaincode?     Can the Invoke send an event or a callback happen after completion of the invoke?  Any examples? Thanks.
<@U1DTE73MW>: the short answer is, the full support is still emerging (see some of the work on “events”)
the SDK will make this largely transparent (once the support is there) by using the “completed” callback
(the callback is there today, but its not closed loop
the SDK just synthesizes the event based on a timeout, rather than a real event
but once that is fixed, you’ll have closed loop confirmation
the online doc for the SDK isnt working, but you want to look at Member.invoke() -> tx.on(“complete”, cb)
fwiw, i am using it here: <https://github.com/hyperledger/fabric-chaintool/blob/master/examples/example02/client/sdk/src/example02/hlc/user.cljs#L23>

One quick question to hyperledger community can the chain code talk amonst other chain code within existing blockchain … Like in Solc one contract can interface with other smart contract if yes then how …
I am failing to find a good example for it
<@U0N1FDZK2> chaincode can talk to another. fabric/examples/chaincode/go/chaincode_example04 and fabric/examples/chaincode/go/chaincode_example05 are the examples.

<@U0N1FDZK2> and <@U0ULK2JPP>: would you not create a significant attack surface without a trustless protocol to exchange data/services/coins across chains? 

I mean, the two chains may speak the same language, but a node on one chain would not be able to prove to itself facts about the other chain.

The security level required would, of course, depend a lot on the nature of the service.
No the point is to lets say there are multiple chaincode running in one chain and interface these multiple chain codes …
Oh ok. So _if_ it were an inter-chain scenario it would be problematic.
<@U20NAT0SF>: its still the same “chain” (ledger)…. and yes, problematic if interchain
Yes agree inter chain scenario would be problematic…
as it would require dealing with 2 or more chains with different states at diffrent time
So... what does this multi-chaincode-per-blockchain scenario imply for scalability, volume, and bloat?
That is, I'm interested in whether multi-chain scenarios are something that would need to be designed for.
If this is the wrong place to have these sorts of high-level discussions, let me know.
Full disclosure: my interest in cross-chain interoperability is because I'm part of a project that's delivering solutions to exactly this problem.
Best use case would be Decentalised exchange …
However lateral use case would come up as integration would play its game …

compose-default.yml: ```vp:

  environment:
    - CORE_PEER_ADDRESSAUTODETECT=true

  # substitution before the value gets to the container
  #command: sh -c "exec $$GOPATH/src/github.com/hyperledger/fabric/bddtests/scripts/start-peer.sh"
  command: sh -c "sleep 5; peer node start --peer-chaincodedev"

  # Use these options if coverage desired for peers
  #image: hyperledger/fabric-peer-coverage
  #command: ./peer.test --test.coverprofile=coverage.cov node start
membersrvc:
   image: hyperledger/fabric-membersrvc
   command: membersrvc```
so after start up and before issuing “deploy” you need to start 4 instances of the chaincode yourself
1) docker inspect <vp0’s container id>
2) get the ip address of vp0 - something like 172.17.0.2 (example)
3) start the chaincode as `CORE_PEER_ADDRESS=<vp0s ip>:7051 CORE_CHAINCODE_ID_NAME=safety_device ./<chaincodeexec>`
and likewise for the other 3 vps
you should hopefully see the chaincodes started and registered with the respective peers
then send the deploy to vp0 as before … you should see all the chaincodes initialized
OK. Let me try. Just to clarify, starting the chaincode require because of `peer-chaincodedev` flag ?
correct
otherwise the chaincodes will be started  by the peer when you do the “deploy"
the “deploy” does two things (1) if not in `—peer-chaincodedev` mode, start the chaincodes and (2) send init to the chaincodes
so in `—peer-chaincodedev` mode you still have to do the “deploy” for (2)

I have not followed that example closely ...
how do you mean _transactions themselves to figure out what happened to a particular vehicle_ ?
I’m sensing some sort of “dynamic” computation … ?

the current process is that we read through every block on the blockchain to read the transactions within it. These transactions store the function call to the chaincode (e.g. create_vehicle) and the arguments passed as well as the caller. In a transfer one of the arguments is the identity of the new owner.

Using this information we can build up the history of the vehicle using the function names as a guide as because we wrote the chaincode we know what the functions do in regards to the vehicle and the order of the arguments.
I see
so the application up the stack manages history instead of maintaining it in the ledger
there are likely many ways to do this
but this way does show the different access paths to the fabric

<@U2DHRR4TE> tables give you query flexibility (though to be honest, the interface could be improved)
<@U0KPFAZNF> how do you mean 'query flexibility'?
i mean, if you break up your “struct” into rows, you can query rows individually
if you glom in into one struct, you have no choice but to return the entire object
for small objects, who cares
but if, for instance, you have 100k rows….
ah right, so it's basically a way of returning bits of large objects as opposed to the entire thing?
correct
(well, also for updates
its a finer granularity of your data, thats all
you can read/write smaller portions of it
which will matter (or not) depending on your data model

the SimpleChaincode struct is because you need to implement the interface that supports the Init/Invoke/Query calls

<@U17CZFXGU> are you running Fabric in development or production mode?
of I see, it looks like dev mode
unlike with BlueMix, you need to run the chaincode locally so that it can listen and receive requests.  something like this:

```
CORE_PEER_ADDRESS=172.17.0.1:7051 CORE_CHAINCODE_ID_NAME=sample ./finished
```

the difference being that BlueMix downloads your chaincode source, builds it, and hosts it in a Docker container as far as I know (i.e. it is in production mode).  In development mode, which is much simpler, you must start your chaincode on your own and let it run so it can receive requests from the peer
<@U17CZFXGU>  I have put instructions here on how to run example02 locally in the simplest way on your local machine: <https://github.com/Bartman250/hyperledgergetgoing>

<@U296PJDD1> is this table functionality based on RocksDB or it's rather something completely new

<@U1CTBUNEN> I had the same question so spent a little time looking at the shim code to answer it.  The table functionality provided by the shim has nothing to do with RocksDB or the underlying data store.    Rather it is just an an abstraction on top of the Fabric's blockchain key-value store.  i.e. when you store a row in the table it just generates a compound key based on the table "fields" that you indicate are part of the key, and then associates the value with that compound key in the key-value store.
<@U23S3DPFY> got it.
I assume at one point you can do SQL-lie queries since it supports index keys

<@U1CTBUNEN> kind of.  lets say you have keys labeled A, B, C, and D.  when I looked the API would let you search for "rows" with values for keys from left to right.  i.e. you can query for A + B + C + D, A + B + C, A + B, or just A

internally though there is no indexing or anything provided by the shim.  I don't know how the blockchain is stored in RocksDB, so maybe there is some help at that underlying level.  In any case, this mostly seems like a toy for building demos to me.

the other take away that I have is that if you were to build a real application, you probably would want to use the blockchain in conjunction with a real database.  e.g. the blockchain would be used to secure the data in the real database
in my mind, there are many unresolved questions regarding how to build real applications with blockchains
<@U23S3DPFY> if there's the KEY field type, I'd assume there's some kind of indexing

I am asking in order to determine the attack surface Fabric-based network is potentially facing (and to determine if issues recently experienced by Ethereum network would also be applicable to Fabric, toutes proportions gardees, of course)
IIUC that wasn't a bug in etherium but a bug in the user code
I am talking about recent 3 weeks and not the DAO hack
oh
i.e. executing smart contracts that perform a buffer overflow on geth and parity clients
i'm uninformed then
basically, if the code is turing-complete, then it is possible to imagine all sorts of malicious intents being injected into the network through the smart contracts
with regards to Fabric the situation is even worse because the smart contract attack surface would not be mitigated by the notion of cost (i.e. gas spent to execute the contract)
what do you mean injected into the network?
you're activating a function
I mean deployed
if you have a bug in the function....
I was just curious if someone is analyzing weaknesses Ethereum network is currently going through in order to avoid similar mishaps or mitigate them within the Fabric code
I think there is a big difference with respect to Fabric in that it is intended for private blockchains.
in what way is this difference articulated?
from a perspective of chaincode?
<@U23S3DPFY> I’d say applies to permissive, permissioned too (not strictly “private”)

fair enough.  the point being is that I wouldn't expect Fabric to be running on the public Internet where just anyone can shovel garbage calls at it.  if a set of businesses are running Fabric on an internal network, and anyone attempts a DOS attack against the nodes, it should be easy enough to identify the source and shut it down

In case of the Fabric, I would implicitly put an intermediary (gateway, DMZ) before a call from the outside would reach the API. I would never let an external application to even reach nodes or query the network through the chaincode directly. However, one must assume that a Turing-complete chaincode opens a new attack surface regardless of the number of boundaries set between it and the outside world. In consortium-like environment it would be hard to enforce the same standard for security among all business participants so as an IT Architect I would not avoid asking such questions or at least documenting it as a risk
so, coming back to my initial question: is chaincode turing-complete to the same extent as solidity-based contracts written for Ethereum network?
<@U2JD3UMEU|vu3mmg> has joined the channel

<@U1P1ZV6RF> As far as I understand, yes. Since Fabric supports writing chaincode in GO lang, Java which are turing complete languages. (However, I don't know about Ethereum's smart contract; so can't compare).
I think, you can create some possible attack scenarios so that fabric experts can see how those can be mitigated.

I think at the moment you can deploy a contract with, for instance, an endless loop an high resource usage. This could easily be mitigated by enforcing a review process for chaincode. In the current version, probably do it offline and give deploy rights to only trusted entities. In the next version, just make sure multiple (maybe even all) approving signatures are required to deploy.

<@U2DHRR4TE> When I used tables, usually you query the table based on the key.  So in your example, I would guess that col1, col2, and col3 are marked as keys that you are querying on.

<@U22RH7VGT> : events are asynchronous.  You can put any value in the event, but it is not something that the client that called invoke will get as a response to the invoke.  You need a separate event listener to listen for and handle the event when the transaction is added to a block.

I'd like to get some clarification on how the key-columns in chaincode tables work.  They're clearly used to identify rows in a given table.  Can a given table have more than one key-column?

The comments in core/chaincode/shim/interfaces.go:GetRows suggest there can be more than one key -- but then what does GetRow do?  Does it have to have all keys specified such that the row is uniquely identified?
<@U2X9KDDL7> : Use CreateTable to create the table.  Then you use GetRow to query for all keys in the table.  GetRows allows you to query by a subset of keys.
So if you CreateTable and specify column A and B as keys, you can use GetRow to query for the row that matches A and B.  Or you could use GetRows to return all the rows with values that match A.
<@U2LV4CC6B> Thanks!

Hi, I have a question about querying tables. I have a table with 3 keys. Example: Surname, Name, RegistryNumber.  If I perform a Lookup with all 3 keys, I'll receive one row. I perform a lookup with keys: Surname, Name, I receive 1 or more  rows. But when I do a lookup by the third key only. I don't receive any information. I perform the lookup as such:  nill,nill, RegistryNumber.   How do I perform a lookup with only the third Key and the other blank values?

<@U2PAN55V0> the simple answer is that the table support is limited and you cannot query (nil, nil, RegistryNumber). Any keybased query ending in a key has to have all the previous keys. (<@U1KFCPFQA> to correct.)
<@U1KFCPFQA|dave.enyeart> has joined the channel
<@U31EJ5JK0|k.sung> has joined the channel
@musalisr, That was my understanding as well. Thanks for the confirmation. I'll try to find another way to circumvent the issue.

<@U0ULK2JPP> That is correct.  The table API is misleading in that you can’t query arbitrary columns.  For v1 we are recommending to use JSON data in chaincode rather than table API, so when using a state database that supports JSON query (such as CouchDB), any field in the chaincode variable can be queried.
<@U1KFCPFQA> - did we decide to remove the table API in v1 (and just expose the range queries) or are we leaving it in?
<@U0PB67X4K> is there a discussion/doc about the chaincode kv interface plans?
I know that we use the table API, and even that is fairly weak for what we would like to see
so, if its going away, id like to know what the plan is in general
e.g. I'd hate to see it get weaker by table simply going away...id rather see it grow stronger

that is the goal… to make it stronger to support query on any field.  we can get there by using JSON data in chaincode and CouchDB as the state database.  Whether we completely remove the fairly limited Table API is still up for debate.
<@U1KFCPFQA> has there been any thoughts on what the chaincode API (for chaincode developers) would look like when it is backed by CouchDB?
<@U1KFCPFQA> having some kind of formal query engine would be a welcome addition
Is there any SDK available for crypto-currency type use case? I mean it should be readily consumable by a front-end designed to make a simple peer-to-peer crypto currency transactions.
my thought is, I would be careful about exposing any one particular engine (unless its super general, like SQL)
but even that,  i dont have a strong opinion other than to say building apps on top of the v0.6 and earlier architecture is a bit weak
so, anything that improves that is welcome

for now we still use PutState() and pass the bytes.  If we detect those bytes represent JSON then we store in CouchDB as JSON, otherwise store in CouchDB as binary attachment.  We may make this more explicit and allow the chaincode developer to call PutStateJSON() or PutStateJSONwithBinaryAttachments().
PutStateJSONwithBinaryAttachments() would allow you to save some queryable JSON ‘header’ information to the ledger, along with binary attachments such as PDF, JPG, etc
All - what are the most typical use cases for query that we are seeing?  a) query to see what is in ledger   or b) query for purpose of determining which keys to update in a transaction?
<@U1KFCPFQA> For me, I query the most to see what's in the ledger

<@U1KFCPFQA> Same for me. One of the things I would find lacking without the table support is how to deal with collections of things - using the car lease demo as an example, I want a collection of cars - I want to get all the cars, I want to get a car by its ID, and ideally I could use a query language to get a car using expressions that can access any of the car's properties.

I don't know much about CouchDB but maybe just storing JSON representations of the cars with some kind of "class" marker would be enough to achieve that with GetState()/PutState() and I assume some kind of Query() method?
right, we could decide to write our own query language on top of key/value database.  haven’t ruled that out, but for short term it is easier to use a database such as CouchDB that already has that.
right, or use one that exists

long story short: some abstraction between the chaincode's interface and the underlying ledger implementation is probably smart, but i agree for the short term its probably fine to surface something less general
out of curiosity: why couchdb?  what else was looked at?
im just curious
I remember looking at couchdb years ago, but i came away relatively unimpressed
IIRC I found its MR facilities were a little too static to be what I deemed useful...i was more enthusiastic about dynamo derivatives like Riak
not saying that is appropriate here, I am just curious what the rationale was
sql based data stores were looked at, but required maintenance of schema which is awkward given our development model
what is MR?
map-reduce
may not apply here
that was what I was looking at at that time
ah, CouchDB in 2.0 has added ad hoc query that does not require map reduce
that makes it much nicer to work with… same idea as sql and mongo query, but different syntax
I seem to recall that I found couchdb a little too static because you had to bake the code in, whereas in Riak you could provide ad hoc queries
ah, gotcha
its been a while since I looked at it, so I am sure its completely evolved at this point
yes, the ad hoc query makes it much nicer for our use
couchdb and mongodb are both good candidates, since the json document approach is similar enough to our core key/value concepts, with good ad hoc query on any fields
<https://hyperledgerproject.slack.com/archives/chaincode/p1478797007002252> . <@U1KFCPFQA>  your initial pluggable state DB presentation had DB2 also as a suggested. Will this still be tried?

<@U2ZT68RU6> If you make all the three fields in your table as key fields, then you can't filter only based on 3rd field. You can do in the following combinations only,
1. select rows based on 1st field value
2. select rows based on 1st and 2nd fields' values
3. select rows based on 1st, 2nd and 3rd fields' values

If you want to select the rows based only on 3rd field, please make only 3rd row as key.  (set false to others).

text:
Need help on Immutability aspect in Blockchain/Hyperledger.  When we create Chaincode, we use the Shim provided capability to create tables in RocksDB.  During transaction invocation on chaincode, we insert and update data in these tables.  Blockchain promises immutability which means updates will not be allowed. However, we are able to update the data on RocksDB.

My questions are,

1. What is the immutability that is provided by Hyperledger
2. I am able to update the records in the DB, because, those tables are created by me, what kind of data gets stored by blockchain. In other words can I avoid creating tables and still invoke transactions? If so agains what the transactions will be invoked? Do we have any samples?
<@U1SHFS1Q9> 1. the immutability means the blocks generated are immutable, you can't alter/delete blocks
2. you can invoke tx w/o creating tables. just see the example02 sample
Does the block store any data other than the hash? Also, if we have tables and create records, how do we correlate the actions on records and the blocks?
I will check our example 2
yes, block also stores payload, timestamp, nonhash data, etc..
block contains your tx in payload, it's like an event, your state(data in tables) will change based on the tx data in block
blocks are like event sourcing, you can play back your state based on the block chain
<https://github.com/hyperledger/fabric/blob/v0.6/protos/fabric.proto#L89>

NonHashData doesn't participate hash process, it only stores local peer data and doesn't change the hash of block.  Actually, Transaction is where data is stored I think. It should be encrypted if you enable privacy option
when calculating Block hash, NonHashData is ignored

Ok. So the payload content is participating in calculating Block hash, right?

My definition of payload is that, if I am implementing an asset management solution using hyper ledger, the  asset details such as its dimensions and other attributes will be the payload.

text: <@U37GEHJSV>: you are correct.  You can only use getRows using the keys in order.  So if you have three keys (k1, k2, k3), you can query on k1 or k1,k2 or k1,k2,k3, but you cannot query on k1,k3 or k2,k3 or k2 or k3.
in the case of querying on k1,k2,k3 your would use getRow though.
I haven’t tried getRows specifying all the keys

you don't need to build from source; you can just start things with Docker Compose and build off of the provided sample app

<@U2T7Z63NY> People here are pretty good at answering questions, although searching slack/stackoverflow/google may find you an answer first. Also note that this channel is specifically for chaincode, not "hyperledger v0.6" in general. What do you want to know?
<@U3AFRMY68> You'd write your chaincode and deploy it once and then 'invoke' it each time you'd like to create a new policy through an SDK or REST call.
<@U2W7U5UA3> sounds fair enough, so that's what I would use the tables for I assume? Can I also store more complex datastructures? Like different fields with values for every 'contract' ?
Yes, the tables/states are where you store your data on the blockchain. You can make the table structure as complex as you like as far as I know.

It's worth looking at IBM's learn-chaincode git
<https://github.com/IBM-Blockchain/learn-chaincode>

not that the end-to-end is not for “—peer-chaincodedev"
that mode has a gotcha
after successful endorsement the chaincode is deregistered by the endorser pending later commit
in non dev mode, the chaincode wil be broight up when you do an invoke
but in `—peer-chaincodedev` mode, after successful commit you’ll have to kill the chaincode and restart it
will likely be fixed at some point that `—peer-chaincodedev` mode does the right thing for dev mode (basically not deregister but let it stay)

hello all together
i have just made my first chaincode tutorial
is it correct that every function in the chaincode is somehow mapped to the public functions Init, Invoke and Query ?
so that fabric knows if it is only a query or it has to write something into the blockchain?
<@U3ESK26BU|mheitz> has joined the channel
<@U3BSMKS21> I would describe it as the other way around
all functions tunnel through either Init, Invoke, or Query
(though generally, theres always only one init
at least, that is how it is when you use the raw chaincode interface
if you use something like chaintool, the tunneling is transparent
but otherwise, yes, you are correct
the system can optimize query types to bypass consensus, and it will also prohibit mutations to ledger state
is there a more elegant way when writing chaincode for the tunneling than using if statements?
what I mean is, when you have several functions which tunnel through Invoke you always have to check which function is called by using an if statement in Invoke
<@U3BSMKS21> Use a switch statement?

Only thing I could find as an alternative is this: <http://stackoverflow.com/questions/8103617/call-a-struct-and-its-method-by-name-in-go>
Personally I'd prefer to stick to the explicit list.

file.name: Mounting_volumes_using_docker-compose.yaml
file.title: Mounting volumes using docker-compose
file.preview:
# This will mount the host folder (on the left) to a folder in your container (on the right)
# This makes all the files and subdirectories available in both places
# If you update files on your host, they will also update in your container!
volumes:
	- /path/on/host:/path/in/container
file.preview_highlight:
# This will mount the host folder (on the left) to a folder in your container (on the right)
# This makes all the files and subdirectories available in both places
# If you update files on your host, they will also update in your container!
volumes:
	- /path/on/host:/path/in/container

initial_comment.comment: <@U1SHFS1Q9> Just for future reference. You can also mount a directory from your host machine onto your docker container by putting something like this in your docker-compose.yml. This is what I do to deploy my chaincode. It means I never need to transfer anything because the chaincode is always up to date.

<@U3BSMKS21> this is a developer mode of operation that runs the chaincode natively (as opposed to having the peer launch a Docker image of your chaincode) thus allowing you to do things such as attach a debugger etc.

<@U3BSMKS21> copying instructions for running in `—peer-chaincodedev` mode in 1.0… (still a bit of WIP but this should work)

```Will use the CLI/Vagrant env for these steps to run in --peer-chaincodedev mode in 1.0

Vagrant window 1 - build peer
   make peer

Vagrant window 2 - start orderer
   cd orderer
   go build
   ./orderer

Vagrant window 2 - start peer in dev mode
   cd peer
   peer node start --peer-chaincodedev

Vagrant window 3 - start chaincode example02 in dev mode
   cd examples/chaincode/go/chaincode_example02
   go build
   CORE_PEER_ADDRESS=127.0.0.1:7051 CORE_CHAINCODE_ID_NAME=mycc ./chaincode_example02

Vagrant window 4 - initialize the chaincode using the "deploy" command
   cd peer
   CORE_CHAINCODE_MODE=dev peer chaincode deploy -n mycc -c '{"Args":["init","a","100","b","200"]}'

   CORE_CHAINCODE_MODE=dev is needed in 1.0 with chaincode deploy. Unlike 0.6/0.7, 1.0 builds the
   chaincode in the deploy command. CORE_CHAINCODE_MODE=dev is needed to tell the deploy command
   not to skip build related activities

#wait for about 10seconds
#kill Ctrl-C chaincode_example02 and start chaincode_example02 again in Vagrant window 3.
#This is needed - for now - as the fabric deregisters the chaincode after deploy

Vagrant window 3 - restart chaincode
   Ctrl-C running chaincode
   CORE_PEER_ADDRESS=127.0.0.1:7051 CORE_CHAINCODE_ID_NAME=mycc ./chaincode_example02

#now you can send invokes and queries as usual from window 4

Vagrant window 4 - send an invoke
   cd peer
   CORE_CHAINCODE_MODE=dev peer chaincode invoke -n mycc -c '{"Args":["invoke","a","b","10"]}’```

^^^ above does not address running from SDK but hopefully has enough details to help you with that as well (basically how do you set the equivalent of CORE_CHAINCODE_MODE=dev in the SDK when doing deploy)

<@U2GG5LADV>  As far as I understand it, chaincode is how you modify the world state, but the world state and the blockchain still exist on the peer even when it's not running.
If you start the peer, start the chaincode, do some transactions, and then stop the chaincode, you will still be able to view the blockchain from the peer.
However, you won't be able to make queries against the world state because those go through chaincode to process.
Without the chaincode you'll still be able to see blocks and transactions.
At least that's been my experience with v0.6

hey <@U3BSMKS21> : it is true that in v0.6, the error that you might expect from the invoke method signature will effectively not be populated...it is a known limitation that is being addressed in v1.0...it is also true with the actual byte[] returned by the invoke method...it won't work either: You will just get the transaction hash, regardless of it being actually fully validated/committed to the chain. If you do want to get going and can't wait for v1.0, I would suggest leveraging the Event (SetEvent method) and using the EventHub within hfc to consume potential outcomes of the invoke (being success or failure)...it is not ideal, but that's possibly one way for you to do what you are trying to do...I guess

hello, I was hoping that someone could provide clarification regarding non-determinism described here (<https://console.ng.bluemix.net/docs/services/blockchain/nondeterministic.html>). Specifically, this sentence "For example, do not run any query transactions in parallel with invoke transactions, because parallel queries could produce variance in the invocation values across nodes.” Does this mean a client should not issue concurrent queries and invokes  ?

<@U1934J6RX> You have to take into account the fact that the query will see only committed blocks, so if you tun queries against commits that are in progress, you will randomly get the before state or the after state, depending on race conditions and other timing issues. If you want the queries to be deterministic, you will want to ensure that a transaction is completed and committed before looking for its results.
<@U0Y55KNG2> thank you. So your app that uses the client might be non-deterministic, but this wouldn’t trigger non-determinism within the chain code and a failure in consensus, correct?

if you write chaincode that depends on the results of a query to another chaincode, you can be burnt by timing issues and have each peer get a differing result. That will cause endorsers to return differing r/w sets and thus will fail consensus.
you need to know that the data is stable before depending on it

OK. In this case, the chaincode does not call any other chaincode, but a client off chain issues concurrent queries and invokes. That wouldn’t trigger consensus failure in the chaincode per se, would it? Thanks again <@U0Y55KNG2>
<@U0P2GSA8Z> `Why do you specify CORE_PEER_MSPCONFIGPATH on every command rather setting it once and for all in your env if it's always the same?` working on that
^^^ trying to wean away from “sampleconfig” as the default now that bootstrap is progressing caused that inconvenience.

No ... but it might create logically inconsistent data in world state. If you are running a state machine in the client and you depend on seeing everything in the right order, and if you don't watch for events that guarantee that the data is stable (i.e. you see a transaction in a block event) then you could end up thinking you are sending the latest state where you are actually sending the previous state again ...
<@U0ULK2JPP> ok

<@U0Y55KNG2> - My understanding, this is coming from the MVCC mechanism used by Couch DB where a read-set getting constructed from multiple keys may not be from a single KV-Ledger snapshot if there is transaction commit getting processed by peer at the same time of query processing.
Thanks again <@U0Y55KNG2> . a related question I had is the ordering of transactions within a block—are they all applied in the same order across nodes?
<@U1934J6RX> Yes, the ordering service ensures that all blocks are identical.
and the transactions within an individual block are applied in the same order?

<@U1934J6RX> Yes. Identical does not have any other interpretation :slightly_smiling_face: ... the ordering service creates what amounts to the block structure and that is passed to all committers. To my knowledge.

<@U3DKG7M54> Well, if the peers are not able to agree on the world state snapshot level for the transaction, then the results will vary and consensus will fail. On the other hand, the creation of the next block in a chain is not done in parallel with other blocks (subchains can be done in parallel but my understanding is that each chain is processed serially for this very reason.) So that means that the chaincode that happens to be executing should be seeing a consistent world state level. No other chaincode can interfere on one chain (and if they start allowing that then good luck with consensus :-))

<@U3DKG7M54> I suppose that the r/w sets could be different if each endorser receives interleaved requests for the same asset keys from different clients. The state of each key will be different across peers. But assume that you can get the required number of endorsers to agree on a r/w set, then you override the others and the orderers ensure that block x+1 is identical across peers.
A well-designed system is not likely to do a lot of the interleaved writes thing ...

In other terms, are deletes in chaincode logical deletions that mask a more permanent storage or does a delete actually end up freeing up storage in rocksdb?
I have been writing chaincode assuming that deletions are real and that by creating and deleting many keys I would not inadvertently use up my whole disk in a real world deployment scenario

<@U2UNR91RB>  - yes - the statedb stores the latest values for each key.  So if you delete a key, you are effectively deleting it from the database.  Of course every transaction is persisted within blocks and blocks are not deleted
<@U0PB67X4K>: Thanks. I am aware that the transaction payload will be persisted, and that may cause some redundancy of what is stored on disk (block data vs app data).

But I might have a transaction that causes me to delete a set of keys, or move their payload under different keys or something, and from what you are saying I understand these types of operations would not affect my storage capabilities in a way I didn't expect. So thanks again :slightly_smiling_face:
of course we are at the mercy of how rocksdb optimizes storage, etc, but your assumptions are correct about deleting keys
Heh. Of course.
Happy New Year, Guys~

<@U2UNR91RB> Rocksdb is hard-coded as the state database in Fabric v0.6, but it is out of the picture in Fabric 1.0 where the state data will use goLevelDB by default, with an optional CouchDB implemenation as well, and other databases can get involved as the state database is pluggable.
<@U0YJUECE8> Wow. Interesting. Pluggable things are great :smile: What was the issue with Rocksdb? I thought it was supposed to be a better LevelDB?
I happen to maintain <http://github.com/bmatsuo/lmdb-go|github.com/bmatsuo/lmdb-go>, so I am always interested in things with pluggable backend storage interfaces :slightly_smiling_face:

<@U2UNR91RB> I don't know the details, and this is just conjecture, but I suspect the reasons may have been more political or license issue oriented, than technical.   But I'll happily stand corrected if I'm wrong about this
Gotcha. I would love some clarification if anyone knows. But it's just a curiosity and not that important.
